“The bricoleur
column2: says Levi-Strauss
column3: is someone who uses ‘the means at hand
column4: ’ that is
column5: the instruments he finds at his disposition around him
column6: those which are already there
column7: which had not been especially conceived with an eye to the operation for which they are to be used and to which one tries by trial and error to adapt them
column8: not hesitating to change them whenever it appears necessary
column9: or to try several of them at once
column10: even if their form and their origin are heterogenous – and so forth. There is therefore a critique of language in the form of bricolage
column11: and it has even been said that bricolage is a critical language itself … If one calls bricolage the necessity of borrowing one’s concepts from the text of a heritage which is more or less coherent or ruined
column12: it must be said that every discourse is bricoleur.” – Jacques Derrida

“HS is supposedly a story that is also a game. In games
column2: the characters die all the time. How many times did you let Mario fall in the pit before he saved the princess? Who weeps for these Marios. In games your characters die
column3: but you keep trying and trying and rebooting and resetting until finally they make it. When you play a game this process is all very impersonal. Once you finally win
column4: when all is said and done those deaths didn’t “count”
column5: only the linear path of the final victorious version of the character is considered “real”. Mario never actually died
column6: did he? Except the omniscient player knows better. HS seems to combine all the meaningless deaths of a trial-and-error game journey with the way death is treated dramatically in other media
column7: where unlike our oblivious Mario
column8: the characters are aware and afraid of the many deaths they must experience before finally winning the game.” – Andrew Hussie

“Lies of omission do not exist. The concept is a very human one. It is the product of your story writing again. You have written a story about the truth

column1: “The love of a blended family never ends” – Unknown

column1: “The secret to blending families is… There is no secret. It’s scary and awesome and ragged and perfect and always changing. Love and laugh hard; try again tomorrow” – Mir Kamin

column1: “Coming together is a beginning. Keeping together is progress. Working together is success” – Henry Ford

column1: “Live one day at a time (or one moment

column1: “Together

column1: “Being happy in your family is more important than being perfect” – Unknown

column1: “It’s about prioritizing. Just take it one step at a time. Do the best you can. I’m a mom and I have two husbands—an ex-husband and a next husband. It’s a blended family and it’s very hard to keep things together

column1: “There is nothing so rewarding as bringing two families together and making it work” – Unknown

column1: “Enjoy the little things in life… for one day you’ll look back and realize they were the big things” – Robert Brault

column1: “The hardest thing about being a blended family is knowing when to fight and when to let it go” – Unknown

column1: “When trouble comes

column1: “Blended families are the best project you’ll ever get to work on” – Unknown

“Remember
column2: ‘this too

column5: the ugly—don’t get too attached to anyone feeling. Also

column1: “The family is one of nature’s masterpieces” – George Santayana

column1: “For those of you that say

column1: “I don’t believe an accident of birth makes people sisters or brothers. It makes them siblings

column1: “If you’re struggling with your role

column1: “You were born with the ability to change someone’s life; don’t ever waste it” – Unknown

column1: “I cannot say whether things will get better if we change; what I can say is they must change if they are to get better” – George C. Lichtenberg
